Anyone for a mocktail? The changes in university drinking culture

22/04/2022

Ella Ward discusses the changing attitudes towards alcohol amongst the Uk's student population.

Image by Edward Eyer

By Hannah Carley

The Beatles, fish and chips, queuing, the Royal Family. Britain is famous, or rather infamous, for many things. But we are also a country known for our drinking culture, with custom dictating a pub visit and a pint for any given excuse. Students at UK universities are among the population famed for their drinking habits, with binge drinking a frequent occurrence among many. With student club nights, Freshersâ€™Â  Week, and studentsâ€™ union bars, universities are full to the brim with alcohol, capitalising on student expectations and demands for cheap drinks.

TV and film have long since portrayed university as an alcohol-fueled train of wild excitement, speedily chugging into a realm of chaos and delight. It is little wonder then, that many prospective students fear being unable to abstain from or moderate their intake of alcohol whilst at university.Â  But the data suggests that students need not fear turning down a pint.

Students used to be big drinkers, and indeed many still are, but research shows that students have been slowing down. A report published by BMC Public Health showed that the proportion of 16 to 24 year-olds drinking above the recommended intake plummeted from 43 percent in 2005 to just 28 percent ten years later. Binge drinking rates also dropped from 27 percent to 18 percent in the same time period. In terms of students specifically, a 2019 study by University College London found that 36 percent of 16 to 24 year-olds in full-time education did not touch a drop. These â€˜non-drinkersâ€™ were found across numerous social groups, suggesting that alcohol abstinence is now a mainstream trend, not restricted to particular religious or cultural practices.

Are students becoming boring? Losing sight of the party? In reality, many students today are simply hard-pressed to find something to celebrate when the supposed â€œbest time of your lifeâ€ is spent fighting the tide of ever-increasing debt and skyrocketing rent. Not surprisingly, there has been an increase in students taking on jobs, with some students almost nearing full-time hours on top of their full-time studies. This is no small feat, and increasing numbers of students simply lackthe time or money to enjoy a drink with friends.

But the pressures on students donâ€™t stop there. With more students attending university than ever before, students are feeling the pressure to achieve excellent grades that will help them stand out from an ever-enlarging crowd. Students have swapped nights out for late-night note taking, reducing student alcohol intake in an effort to pull off first-class grades. Health and fitness too have taken an unprecedented forefront in student lives, and for many alcohol is just not conducive to the bodies they want to obtain. Nights in have become the new nights out, with the data reflecting this change.

On a student scene once characterised by excessive drinking, sober students could feel shunned or excluded. Alcohol has greased the wheels of university social life for so long that many students who abstained lacked opportunities to interact. But the teetotal social scene has been on the rise in universities, reflecting drop-ping trends in alcohol consumption. The overall decline in drinking has made it more socially acceptable among students to turn down a pint. Dr Linda Ng Fat, lead author of the UCL study, claims that â€œIt seems that non-drinking is becoming more normative, which could make it easier for more and more young people not to drink, should they choose to.â€ There has been a growing number of student societies and university events for non-drinkers in recent years. The University of York is home to the Sober Society, a group dedicated to socialising sans alcohol. Perhaps surprisingly, its doors are open to drinkers as well as non-drinkers, with a focus on sober interaction within the group, whether or not members may drink outside of that setting.

Universities have proved eager to board the sober train started by students, perhaps keen to shed reputations of excessive and dangerous drinking cultures in universities. The University of St Andrews now offers â€˜Alcohol-Free Accommodationâ€™, an option for students who wish to avoid drinking and drunken behaviour. Students who choose this option enter into an agreement to not drink alcohol on the premises and will be removed if they do so. Of course, St Andrews is offering a rare opportunity that most universities do not provide, but other universities have been quick to support sober students in different ways.

Leeds University Union welcomed its freshers with the promise that â€œthe idea that you can only get involved with the fun if youâ€™re up for going out drinking is far from true.â€ In an effort to cater for more studentsâ€™ needs, they diversified their Freshers Week events, â€œmaking sure that every single student [could] get involved, make friends, and have fun, no matter their preferences or beliefs.â€

York has similarly promoted non-drinking activities to its students, with articles published on its Student Voices blog that offer advice on fun but alcohol-free activities. Colleges too have embraced the trend with many incorporating club night alternatives into their Freshers and Refreshers timetables.

Universities and students are making the effort to make recreation more inclusive. But in her October 2021 interview with Nouseâ€™s Ed Halford, Amy McKee, President of Sober Society, admitted that there is â€œdefinitely a stigmaâ€ towards students who donâ€™t drink, with some students â€œacting strangeâ€ around non-drinkers, particularly if sobriety is a personal choice rather than a religious or medical requirement. But whilst McKee has faced some discomfort from students, she concedes that younger students are much more accepting and supportive of her choices. Attitudes towards drinking seem to be changing rapidly, with students becoming increasingly confident in tackling what has for so long been the norm.

Sobriety has obvious benefits to studentsâ€™ physical health and bank balances. But the latest National Union of Students study on alcohol impact from2018 has revealed that decreasing drinking amongst students has improved student behaviour too. A 50 percent increase in non-alcoholic events during Freshers Week and a 20 percent decrease in students pre-drinking regularly in halls coincided with a 40 percent drop in students excluded from campus venues due to intoxication. Importantly, there was also a 50 percent reduction in major fights and verbal assaults occurring on nights out.

So attitudes are indeed changing, with students drinking less overall. But this is a tale of two halves: some students may have ditched the drink, but for many students, binge drinking is still a regular occurrence. The NHS defines binge drinking generally as drinking more than six or eight units of alcohol in one session for women and men respectively, with six units equating to two pints of beer or two large glasses of wine. Perhaps unsurprisingly then, many students are frequently engaging in behaviour that the NHS brands as dangerous. Universities are well aware of such drinking habits, with the University of York offering advice and resources for students on alcohol and the dangers of drinking to excess, including links to Drinkawareâ€™s â€œFreshersâ€™ Week Survival Guideâ€. Drinkaware urges students to know their limits, eat before drinking, and skip out on too many pre-drinks. Their advice might sound simple, but it could be life saving.

In his book, Drugs Without the Hot Air, David Nutt argues that alcohol is the most dangerous drug available to us. â€œTo put the danger of alcohol into perspective, it is one of the only drugs that can kill you if you stop taking it abruptly while physically dependent,â€ he says. â€œMaking it incredibly difficult to quit without specialist support.â€ Although not everyone who drinks will develop an addiction, Nutt estimates that 10-15 percent of drinkers will become dependent. Recovery Connections, a charity based in Teesside, has recognised the drinking problem in universities, raising awareness of addiction on campuses. They offer local support for students struggling with alcohol, and have founded Higher Education and Recovery Talk (HEART), a platform to support students nationally. HEART works to â€œnavigate the added pressures of freshersâ€™ weeks, student nightlife, socialising and any other potential triggers such as exams and deadlinesâ€ for students struggling with addiction.

HEART recognises that â€œwhile there is much understanding and support in higher education around mental health and equality and diversity, addiction and recovery remains largely unspoken of in many university settings.â€ HEART intends to challenge this silence, but the lack of support offered by universities for those suffering from addiction is staggering. Perhaps institutions are fearful that acknowledging addiction means ac-knowledging alcohol problems on campus - not a great look for their all-important public images. But now more than ever, this support is crucial. Student Minds has revealed that 74 percent of students experienced a negative impact on their mental health because of the pandemic, with two thirds experiencing feelings of loneliness and isolation.

HEART has recognised that such feelings of isolation are a major trigger for addictive behaviours and a hamper to progressing recovery. Indeed, the pandemic saw a rise in drinking for adults overall, with many struggling to adjust to severe social restrictions. With mental health problems on the rise and second year students still acclimatising to student life after lockdown cut short their social life as Freshers, there are more students than ever before potentially vulnerable to alcohol misuse.

As a group, students might be drinking less, but this doesnâ€™t mean there arenâ€™t students at high risk because of their alcohol intake. More students may have opted out, but the drinking culture at universities is still alive and well, and following the pandemic, drinking may even be on the rise again. But whatâ€™s important is that whatever students choose to drink or not drink, they and the people around them are safe whilst doing it.
